details.publicNotes:
Long ago, there was a poor Sea Gnoll named Ayash who was born of a very possessive and controlling chieftain named Aioswe who resented his son for being more beloved by his multitude of wives than him. One day, Aioswe went hunting and returned to find intimate marks on Ayash's mother. Aioswe knew that she had been unfaithful, but was so blinded by jealousy that he blamed the marks on Ayash having an incestuous affair. As Aioswe took his son far out to the oceanic depths, he clubbed him on the back of the head to knock him out and abandon him.

Ayash was unconscious for a long while but Nanaboozhoo had found and delivered Ayash to the Wazashk Foundry while he was unconscious. While that was all the trickster god was able to accomplish in his busy schedule, he knew there were plenty of Corsikans and Sea Gnolls there to help train him for the epic journey ahead. By the time Ayash completed training, he was a very sly but also very ruthless god of war. Nothing his father put in his path would be enough to stop him, Ayash always had a cunning plan to come out on top.

When Ayash completed his journey, the ensuing fight against his father was fire and fury the likes no Gem Gnoll alive had seen before. But after the destruction, Ayash comforted his crying mother by reminding her that after the fire comes regrowth, and that she should hold onto this diamond pendant, drilled to contain a drop of blood within it. He promised her that as long as it exists, he will always stand ready in the astral plane to lend a willing hand to her or her descendants, with whatever they needed to see their struggles through. Ayash claimed that he didn't want to travel to the Outer Planes and wanted to continue helping.

In the many eons since then, many gnoll warriors who manage to defy the odds and die a craftsmen's death have made pacts with blood diamonds in such a similar manner and became known as Warriors of Ayash, and after Apep's scouring of fire, many Gem Gnolls prayed for these ancestors to come and help them rebuild society underground. Alas, as the astral world is known for distorting space in the material world, what these spirits sacrificed for spatial accuracy was paid for with temporal accuracy, and thus it is not uncommon for such spirits to arrive even as far into the fall of the empire, and likely even farther. Many faithful followers of Soft Whisper hunt down such forgotten pendants through highly scrutinous genealogy and either find a descendant to whom the pendant will answer in order to convince the spirit to stand down, or by destroying it if no such descendant can be feasibly found.

description.value: These spirits are capable of walking between the Astral Plane and the Material Plane with unparalleled spatial precision, and can possibly guide a party with this technique. However this spatial precision requires temporal precision to be sacrificed, the inaccuracies of traveling through the astral plane are paid in time experienced on the Material Plane. a trip that could take a party month to make on the astral plane could end up causing years to pass when the party returns. It is thus best to save this for short trips.

These warriors lived to a ripe old age by being clever and cunning, and this has only become even easier for the gnolls in death. Due to their incorporeal nature but by using tools with Ghost Touch enchantments, these Gnolls know how to set traps, magical or otherwise, to corner their prey no matter what it may look like or how safe it may feel. Any adventurer going up against them best be prepared for anything

You shake the ground, topple creatures into fissures, and collapse structures. The GM might add additional effects in certain areas. Cliffs might collapse, causing creatures to fall, or a lake might drain as fissures open up below its surface, leaving a morass of quicksand.

  • Shaking Ground The ground is difficult terrain, and creatures on it take a -2 circumstance penalty to attack rolls, AC, and skill checks. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spell-effects.Item.09rtx50laDw68FGT]{Spell Effect: Earthquake (Shaking Ground)}
  • Fissures Each creature on the ground must attempt a Reflex save at the start of its turn to keep its footing and avoid falling into 40-foot-deep fissures that open beneath it. The fissures are permanent, and their sides require successful @Check[athletics|dc:15|traits:action:climb] to Climb.
  • Collapse Structures and ceilings might collapse. The GM rolls a flat check for each (@Check[flat|dc:16] for a sturdy structure, @Check[flat|dc:14] for an average structure and most natural formations, @Check[flat|dc:9] for a shoddy structure, all adjusted higher or lower as the GM sees fit). A collapse deals 11d6 bludgeoning damage to each creature caught in it with a basic Reflex save. A creature falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} unless it critically succeeds and falls into a fissure if it critically fails.

Heightened (10th) You create a massive earthquake that can devastate a settlement. The range increases to half a mile and the area to a quarter-mile burst.

The targets experience a day's worth of recovery in an instant. Any detrimental effects that would be gone after 24 hours end, though this doesn't shorten the duration of any active spells affecting the targets. The targets regain Hit Points and recover from conditions as if they had taken 24 hours of rest, but they do not make their daily preparations again or gain any benefits of rest other than healing. The targets are then temporarily immune for 1 day.

You fire a blue-white ray of freezing air and sleet that deals 10d8 cold damage. Make a spell attack roll against the target.

Critical Success The target takes double damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2}

Success The target takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2}

Heightened (+1) The damage increases by 2d8
